Table of Contents for current page

Classic matrix differentiation ​

For a given matrix A and its corresponding function f(x)=xTAx, we have

∇xf(x)=(A+AT)x.

Specifically, if A is a symmetry matrix, i.e., AT=A, then

∇xf(x)=2Ax.
  • For clarity, we take a two-dimensional matrix as an example. Denote x,A as
x=[x1x2],A=[abcd],

then

f(x)=xTAx=ax12+(b+c)x1x2+dx22.
  • Taking the derivative of f(x) with respect to x1 and x2 yields
∇xf(x)=[2x1+(b+c)x2(b+c)x1+2dx2]=([abcd]+[acbd])[x1x2]=(A+AT)x.
  • For the least square problem,
J(x)=∥Ax−b∥2=(Ax−b)T(Ax−b)=xTATAx−2bTAx+bTb,

then ∇xf(x)=2ATAx since ATA is a symmetry matrix.

Sum of Least Squares problems ​

∙ The minimization problem of the sum of the objective functions in least squares problems is equivalent to solving the sum of the corresponding normal equations.

For the sum of two objective functions in least square problems, i.e.,

J(x)=∥A1x−b1∥2+∥A2x−b2∥2=(A1x−b1)T(A1x−b1)+(A2x−b2)T(A2x−b2),

taking its derivative and setting it to zero yields the globally optimal conditions (also referred to as the system of normal equations):

(A1TA1+A2TA2)x=A1Tb1+A2Tb2.

Additionally, by combing them into a new least square problem, i.e.,

minx|[A1A2]x−[b1b2]|2,

we can obtain the same normal equation as above.
